text: ...on a BLACK WAVE - vast, oceanic, and coming right at u BEGIN TITLES. The wave is relentless, huge, menacing. We can't tell if is daytime or night because it simply obscures everything noisily. It sucks, it yawns, it roars. Then we realize... this massive wave of darkness is actua just a RUN-OFF of dirty black WATER alongside the edge of Interstate. We PULL OUT OF IT now... ...to find concrete, and garbage, and weeds. END TITLES. 1   EXT. DITCH - OFF THE INTERSTATE - 4:30 A.M. Amongst the refuse is a discarded MILK CARTON, resting on back. The carton asks "Have You Seen Me?" above a photogr face that's been obscured by grime. Yellowing newspaper, old Coke cans, Twinkie wrappers... i that bed of untended weeds. A hollow Texas wind blows thr it all. We stay with the carton... Then that hollow wind gains speed... and a deep RUMBLE gr in the distance, becoming a ROAR. The yellowed newspaper off and whips past us. ...as an 18-WHEEL MACK TRUCK blows by, just a blur in the corner of our frame, doing 75 in the pre-dawn darkness. Then, the truck is gone, and the rush of air dissipates. milk carton, the coke cans... they lie undisturbed. A LIGHT RAIN begins to fall... and some of the grime wash away from that milk carton, revealing a face. A child. "H You Seen Me?" It's heartbreaking. TILT UP... to take in the vast flatness of Texas' I-35: concrete forever. In the distance, gray highway yields to black STORMCLOUDS gathering silently over endless prairie A vertical vein of LIGHTNING streaks through one of them.
...a spoon, stirring a cup of coffee.

HAROLD SPECK sits: mid 40's, pleasant face. A family man. Reads "Rod and Reel" magazine. Has a SALESMAN'S CASE by h side. Around him is a TRUCK-STOP in twilight: Truckers at the counter, Elvis on the wall, a "Drink Bud! mirror. The WORLD SERIES can be heard on a RADIO...

Top that off for ya, Hon? That's DOLLY, a waitress, (50, been here too long.) Speck looks up, smiles thinly, "No." Dolly heads off. Speck ret to his article, underlining a particular passage. ...until a MAN seats himself, suddenly, in the seat oppos Speck's. Speck reacts, startled.
Jesus... The MAN's name is O'RYAN. We only see PIECES of him: his his hands, a stain on his parka...
What's in the case?
I'm sorry?
You're always lugging that case around. I'm curious. Speck looks around: there are plenty of empty tables in h So why is this guy bothering me???
What do you sell?
I'm... in restaurant supplies. I didn't get your name?
Must travel a lot, huh? Speck is looking for Dolly, a Manager, anyone...
Whole country, or just hereabouts?
I don't mean to be rude but--
How's your wife feel about it? That spun things a bit. Speck pauses.
What?
She must get lonely, with you gone all the time. Does she?
Look, I...
Do you get lonely? Speck's so thrown now he can't answer.
Ya miss fucking her, Harold?

Listen, I don't know who you are but you can't-- O'Ryan silences him... by holding up a piece of paper. On is a DRAWING. The image faces away from us. But Speck can it in rich detail. And his eyes go wide. We catch GLIMPSES: The color of flesh. A body-part. Looks a rendering of a young, naked WOMAN. And, just like that, Speck finds himself STARING. Glued.
Did it myself. It's sort of a hobby. (no reply) I've got more. Would you like to see them? O'Ryan lowers it and slides a SECOND DRAWING over... Spec speechless, transfixed. Can't look away.
Tell me: those jokes about the traveling salesman and the farmer's daughter - are they true?

(Speck remains silent) Here. This one's my favorite. O'Ryan slides over DRAWING #3. Again, we don't get to see And we still haven't seen all of O'Ryan's face. But we can see Speck, and his reaction. Utter horror. In he recoils so violently that his coffee spills.
Really says it all, wouldn't you agree?
You're a... You're sick.
That's a matter of opinion.
You're sick! He rises, leaving the drawings behind. We STAY WITH HIM a crosses the diner - deeply unsettled. He reaches the Mana (MEL, balding, 50, in no mood) at the register.
Mmm-hmm?
I'm having a problem - with another customer. I'd like you to ask him to leave, please.
What kind of problem?
He's-- He turns, to point out O'Ryan. ...but the booth, suddenly, is empty. The guy has simply disappeared, taking those drawings with him. Speck tightens. Mel eyes him, annoyed.
Speck hurries out to his Buick, checking over his shoulde repeatedly. Gets to the car, fumbles with his keys. They to the asphalt. He grabs them, opens the door.

Speck guns the Buick. Interstate 35 flies by. The farther gets away from that Diner, the happier he'll be. ...until a strange SOUND gets his attention: it's WIND, a whistling through a ghost town. Hollow, varied - building falling off again. Wind. Trouble is, the windows in this Buick are up. Yet there it is again: a thin, hollow GHOST-TOWN WIND, whistling over his shoulder. He's heard it before - in ev Western he ever watched as a kid. But this wind is coming from his back-seat. The blood drains right out of Speck's face. Doesn't know should jam on the brakes or drive faster. He looks in his rear-view, catches a glimpse of a LATEX G snapping onto a hand. Dear God: O'Ryan is back there, mak that odd Ghost-Town wind sound. Whistling.
(sheer terror)

What-do-you-want?! What-do-you-want-with- me?! No reply. Instead, another gift appears from the back: a FOURTH DRAWING, tossed from the darkness into Speck's lap He looks down, registers the image... and SHRIEKS.
There's a rest stop, next off-ramp. Pull into it.
I have some money. It's not a lot but--
Nobody wants your money, Harold. Just pull in.
Why?! O'Ryan rises into frame now, like Nosferatu...
Because I don't wanna do this at 70 miles an hour. It could be dangerous. Speck finds the off-ramp. His breaths are shallow now.
Please, Mister - what do you want from me? O'Ryan's face: a knowing grin fans across it...
...the face of VIRGIL RAY STARKEY, on a bulletin board.

We're looking at the F.B.I.'s "Ten Most-Wanted List." Sta is #7 on it. He's 40, white. His crime are listed as rape murder, kidnapping. THOMAS MACKELWAY stares at Starkey's image. At the eyes.. Mackelway is 34, bred for success - bred for stardom in f a whiz at everything he's ever attempted. So what the hell is he doing in Wichita Falls, Texas...? EIGHT AGENTS, in cubicles, with a ring of outer offices. phones, lousy take-out options, hardly a dream gig.
Got a spot set up for you, Tom. That's RICK CHARLTON: late 40's, thinning hair, friendly. Charlton heads around a corner. Mackelway follows.

Ms. Potter's the nice girl you met at the desk. She puts a package together for all the new agents, things to know about the area, help with finding apartments and such. This one's yours: Charlton stops at a CUBICLE: Carpeted walls, formica desk corner of dull Hell. Mackelway eyes it, fighting dread.
Not so different from Dallas, is it?
(fuck yes)
No, Sir.

Good. An abandoned SPORTS PAGE tells us about that World Series we must be mid-October. Charlton heads out. Mackelway thr briefcase on to the desk, setting up his world: A framed picture of himself and his BROTHER, ages 10 and on a childhood camping trip. Address book, coffee-warmer, calendar, a baseball covered with autographs. He opens up a drawer, and casually tosses two bottles of BUFFERIN into the back of it. ...but first grabs four tablets from one of the bottles, and throws them down his throat, as:
Ya like Frito Pies? Mackelway turns. BILL GRIEVES stands here, holding a whit grease-stained paper-bag. Grieves is Mackelway's age, not quite as ambitious. But solid, decent.
I dunno. What are they? Grieves pulls out a greasy concoction that's wrapped up l semi-burrito. Pure Texas. Tosses it to Mackelway:
Welcome to the minors. Grieves passes by with a faint smile, handing out lunch t few other agents. Mackelway eyes the still-wrapped Frito God, get me outta here...
A BRIEF MONTAGE: Mackelway, in his cubicle, watching as T OTHER AGENTS take calls, strap on guns, head out on assignment. Men in motion.

But Mackelway's land-locked, writing up an Auto-Theft rep It's drudgery, but he's meticulous about it, deleting the "beige" and replacing it with "tan." His head is throbbing - not an unusual circumstance for h But after lingering for a half-second on that "Most-Wante List" again? Starkey? It's a wound...
Mackelway struggles with a COFFEE MACHINE that's unfamili him. Filter, water, grounds, etc.
Here. Lemme do that. He turns. This is KATIE POTTER. She's 25, friendly, under challenged by her job. Been here two years. In two second she's got the thing percolating. Of course.
It takes some experience. He shrugs, not feeling too smooth.
You're Mackelway, right?
Mmm-hmm.
Fax came in for you. It's the room next door.
Oh. Thanks. He rises, heads for the "fax room"...

A former closet, converted into useful space. FIVE FAX MACHINES sit on stands, sharing a surge protector. One fa machine is printing. Mackelway approaches it. Six pieces of paper await him. The first is a TOP-SHEET, written by hand: "Attention: Agent Thomas Mackelway, FBI Resident Agency - Wichita Falls." No sender named. He looks beneath the top sheet - at Page One of the fax.

A young BOY stares back at him, his face photostatically copied. Across the top, also-handwritten: "HAVE YOU SEEN At the bottom of the sheet, typed, we read: "Jason Corey, Age 14. Ht. 5'1", Wt. 130, Eyes Brn, Hair B Last Seen: Riverside, Ca. Date of Disappearance: 10-16-99 Mackelway eyes the face, then the vitals. No idea why thi sent to him. Then he looks at Page Two. A young WOMAN stares back at him this time. Another faxed photo. Another "HAVE YOU SEEN ME?" scrawled across the to it. And, at the bottom of the sheet: "Anna Casitas, Age 22. Ht. 5'6", Wt. 125, Eyes Brn, Hair Last Seen: Macon, Ga. Date of Disappearance: 5-6-00." The other three faxes are more of the same: Pictures and vitals. Faces. Facts. "HAVE YOU SEEN ME?" He looks at the bottom of the transmissions, finds the fa number of the sender. Dials it. All he hears back is the grainy shriek of a dedicated fax line. He eyes the faxes again. It's not alarming, but it's odd. Charlton emerges from his office, shouting:
Mackelway! You gonna sit on your ass all day, or do you wanna do something? Mackelway's out of this room in an instant.

Your standard roadside rest-stop: a parking lot with weed poking through it and bathrooms you wouldn't go near. Tho STORMCLOUDS we saw earlier are CLOSER now... POLICE CARS and HIGHWAY PATROL MOTORCYCLES fill this site Charlton's FBI SEDAN pulls up. He and Mackelway get out. Two men approach: SHERIFF HARRY DYLAN, 50; and his deputy GRANGER, a gangly, baby-faced pup.
Afternoon, Rick. (Charlton nods)
Looks like a robbery/homicide. Body's over that way.

He gestures toward a ravine, where a TOW TRUCK is current lowering a winch toward an abandoned vehicle. It is Harold Speck's Buick, nose-down in the ravine, teet on a rock, like the balanced scales of justice.
Ya run the plates? Charlton eyes Mackelway: "Easy, Hot-shot." Mackelway nods reminding himself to remember his new rank. Dylan hands a preliminary report to Charlton.

Fella's name is Harold Speck. Traveling salesman, from Abilene. Charlton eyes the report, then hands it to Mackelway. The hierarchy is being made clear. Very. Mackelway turns: this ravine runs right up against a SIGN reads "Welcome to Texas" on one side and "You are now lea Oklahoma" on the other. A vehicle, left right on the state-line. Odd... Then, a NOISE: that Tow-Truck WINCH, grinding badly. It's about to yank the Buick out of this ditch.
(it blurts out)
Hey! Before Charlton can react, Mackelway is running across th weed-choked lot, zeroing in on the TOW-TRUCK DRIVER.
The Driver, JUMBO, is operating the winch from a hydrauli handle on the back of the truck. Mackelway barrels in:
What the fuck're you doing?!
What's it look like, Bud? Mackelway reaches past Jumbo and hits the "Stop" button himself. The winch shuts down. Mackelway turns. A handful LOCAL COPS stand atop this ravine, watching.
You guys ever heard of evidentiary procedure? No one replies. Charlton approaches. Mackelway tightens, expecting a reprimand for overstepping his bounds.
Sorry, Sir. There wasn't time. Charlton eyes the car. Then Mackelway.

Did the right thing, Agent Mackelway. Let's have a look. Charlton starts down the embankment. Mackelway doesn't, hanging back as he eyes the TRACKS this Buick made before tumbling. Something about them... He pulls a small CAMERA from his pocket, a Minox. Snaps o few photos of the scene - the Buick, the ravine, those tr some FOOTPRINTS alongside them. Then he heads down the 15-foot embankment.

It's an ugly sight. Speck is inches from us, but his head facing in the other direction, twisted unnaturally. Mackelway kneels beside the open window, pulls out some gloves, puts them on. He will not lean on the car, or eve breathe on it, his caution around evidence obvious.

What's that? Charlton is opposite him, outside the passenger-side wind pointing at the DRAWING that O'Ryan had tossed onto Speck lap. It lies face down on the seat. But something's been FINGER-PAINTED on the back of it: A RED CIRCLE, with a SLASH through it. Charlton begins to reach for it, when:
(to stop him)
Sir? Charlton stops. Mackelway indicates: "Gloves."
Charlton eyes him. It's irritating being corrected by a g you outrank, especially when he's right. MACKELWAY (CONT'D)
Sort of a... stickler for procedure. CHARLTON
I imagine you would be. That was a jab, but we don't know it yet. Charlton puts o gloves. Mackelway snaps off a few more shots with that Mi looking over the rest of this car, as: GRANGER

(aloud) Hey Jumbo. Toss me down a crowbar. Granger's by the trunk. Before Mackelway can comment, Jum has tossed a CROWBAR down from the top of the embankment: ten-pound hunk of iron, flying right at us. Everybody ducks... as it CLANGS on the roof of the Buick. Jumbo shrugs. JUMBO
You said toss it. Mackelway shakes his head. "Shitkicker." Granger grabs th crowbar. He's just about to open the trunk as: MACKELWAY

Hold it a second. Granger pauses. Mackelway crosses to the trunk, and snaps a few shots with the Minox. Something catches his eye, along the line of the TRUNK. H kneels closer... An odd RESIDUE, crusty and hard, has for thin line on top of the paint in a single post. He takes out a VIAL, and scrapes some of the residue into Then he sniffs it. Pauses... MACKELWAY (CONT'D)
Smells like... clove. He looks to Granger: now you can open the trunk. DYLAN
(re: Mackelway) Where the hell'd you find this guy?
Field Office. Dallas.
(impressed)
Well now... (Charlton shrugs)

So what the hell's he doin' here? That one is left unanswered. Granger opens the trunk. Mackelway and the others look inside... There, they find restaurant supplies: napkin dispensers, shakers, ketchup dispensers, a short-order wheel... And a fishing reel, tackle-box, a kid's bicycle helmet. Mackelway eyes it all, but his instincts tell him there's nothing significant here. So he returns to Speck's body. He leans in, lifts Speck's head a few inches away from th steering wheel. Gently. ...which is when we learn that Speck's EYELIDS have been off. It's gruesome, but Mackelway notes it calmly. Charlt leans in, gets a look.
Christ... Mackelway is expressionless. But something about these LI EYES draws him closer. He leans in, then BAM! We are rock into a series of dark, disjointed images:

Seems like we're standing in a field of TALL WHEAT; we ca say for sure. Everything's wet, wind-whipped. A MUZZLE FLASH... Someone just fired a gun. We slump hard the ground. Then we look up. Mackelway stands over us, his face wet with rain. Then, j as quickly, those IMAGES VANISH and we are:

We start on the EYES OF O'RYAN. Cross-Dissolve to a pad o paper, on a DESK. Scrawled on the pad is a WAVY LINE. He the tip of that pen upon it, for a few seconds, as if expecting to get some kind of pulse from it. Here come those IMAGES again: wet wheat, a muzzle flash, Mackelway. Choppy, disjointed, dark. Then they cease...

...and O'Ryan begins to DRAW, hurriedly. Only half of his is visible to us, but we can tell that his concentration total. His pen continues its furious work, a spasm of activity, the SOUNDS of that vision bleed in: the gun-shot, the rai the wind. They're all alive in O'Ryan's mind... And that DRAWING takes shape quickly: The wheat field, th gun, Mackelway. Then, the pen is set down. The drawing is complete. O'Ryan eyes it calmly, then checks his watch, jotting dow exact time and date on to the drawing. Then he slips it i folder marked, "MACKELWAY."
Picket fence, a swing on the porch, a lawn that needs mow A LINE OF PEOPLE file in, each bringing food... and tissu cry into.

Shocked faces. Food on unmatching trays. Speck's wife - J 40 and frayed - sits in a chair, immobile. FRIENDS and FA mill about, tending to her. KIDS hover. Two of them, a 4-YEAR-OLD BOY and an 8-YEAR-O GIRL, sniff back tears as people offer condolences. But the focus here is Jan - her grief. She's shaking...
Mrs. Speck? She looks up. O'Ryan crouches down, to eye-level, one of faces in here. Jan half-nods.
Just wanted to offer my condolences. (takes her hand)
I didn't know him well but... I think Harold was a much more complex man than people realized. Jan is so raw that anything about Speck touches her now.
(through tears)
He was, wasn't he?

I'm very sorry for your loss, ma'am. She sniffs back a tear, thanks him with a smile. O'Ryan extends his hand to her. She takes it. He moves off. Beside her is a FRAMED PORTRAIT of Speck. We blow past it into the BLACK CREPE that is adorning the corner of the portrait's FRAME, and: BAM! We're rocketed back into a set of odd IMAGES again:
This time, everything before us is a blur of gray. We hea that wet wind. We hear our own heavy BREATHING, as if we running somewhere... a VOICE, rising above the wind, seem be saying:

Please... The sound echoes oddly, as if bouncing off a satellite somewhere, or a distance of time and space. Then the sound and the soupy grayness VANISH. This vision ended. When we pop back out of it, we're TIGHT on Mackelw

Mackelway sits behind the wheel of his Chevy Yukon, parke between two big-rigs in the lot of the "All-American Dine Sky looks black tonight. It rumbles... And that soupy gray vision we just heard and saw... It wa his. He pulls four more Bufferins out of a bottle in his pocke Slugs them down. This headache is a constant. Then he get of the Yukon...
Mackelway enters, spots Charlton at a booth - sitting opp a WOMAN, her back to us.
Mackelway approaches. The Woman doesn't turn.

Agent Mackelway. I was 'bout to introduce you, but I understand that won't be necessary. Mackelway doesn't get it... until the WOMAN turns. She is AGENT FRAN KULOK. 35, sharp, pretty when she allows herse be. But with a guard that never comes down. Mackelway has some history with her, so he tries not to r It takes some effort.
Seems your former office has decided we might need some help on this one. So they sent out Agent Kulok.
Tom.
Fran. That was terse, from both of them. Charlton takes note.
I guess we're skipping the tearful reunion. Have a seat, Tom. Mackelway sits opposite Fran. She folds her hands.
How's things back at the ranch?
Movin' right along. That might've been a dig; Charlton can't tell.
Okay. Whadda we know?
Picked up a foot-print in the back seat of Speck's car, size-and-a-half bigger than Speck's. Just like that, Fran is piping up. Mackelway's unoffended
CHARLTON
'Kay. FRAN

Wounds on Speck's throat indicate that he was strangled from behind... I think our guy waited for him in the backseat, sprung this on him once the car was moving. She slides that FOURTH DRAWING to Charlton - giving us ou first look at it.

...a STEAMER-TRUNK, lined with plastic. Inside it are lar ZIPLOC BAGS. Inside the bags are BODY PARTS. It's realized so accurately that it looks more like a photograph. No wonder it horrified Speck so deeply.
Charlton eyes it without reaction. FRAN (CONT'D)

Lab picked up talcum traces on the edges of the paper, consistent with powdered gloves. (Charlton nods) So he gets the dropped in his lap, it spooks him, and the car winds up in the ravine. Plausible enough, until: MACKELWAY
I don't think so, no. I think it was pushed. FRAN
How ya figure? MACKELWAY

The look of the tracks. Foot-prints near the embankment. Without embellishing any further, he slides over the PHOTOGRAPHS that he took this morning with the Minox: tir tracks, foot-prints. She eyes them. Then she eyes Mackelway. Charlton notes the tension.
CHARLTON

Okay. So our guy likes to draw pictures of body parts and then spring 'em on people. What's that get us? (they're silent) That's what I thought. There is plenty going unsaid here between Mackelway and F Charlton has no time for it. CHARLTON

Oh. 'Fore I forget. This came in for you: He tosses a 9-by-12 ENVELOPE at Mackelway, who opens it. sheets of paper slide out. First one we see is the TOP SHEET of a FAX: same hand-wri inscription as the last one: "Attention, Agent Thomas Mackelway, FBI Resident Agency, Wichita Falls." Okay. This is twice now. He knows what will be under this sheet without even looking. But here's Page One: A photo of a middle-aged African-American WOMAN. Across t top of the photo, in hand-writing: "HAVE YOU SEEN ME?" And typed on the bottom: "Tanya Green. Age 42. Ht. 5'9", 165, Eyes Blk, Hair Blk. Last Seen: Ames, Iowa. Date of Disappearance: 3-22-97." The following four sheets bring four more faces: men, wom young, old. Four more HAVE YOU SEEN ME's. But before he can think it through, he hears: MANAGER (O.S.)
It's about time. They turn. That came from the NIGHT MANAGER: a humorless named LES. He's looking at the front door, through which has just entered. Pink cowboy boots tonight. DOLLY
Don't start in on me, Les. I couldn't get the pickup started and Harlan took the Dodge. The Manager now throws a glance at the three feds in the booth. Dolly stops short, taken aback.
Holy Hell. My one shot at winding up on "Cops" and I'm in my weekday boots!
Dolly and Mel sit opposite Mackelway and Fran.
He was a quiet guy. Normal. Liked to read fishing magazines. Not much of a tipper. Is that a lousy thing to say?
It's fine. Mel rolls his eyes.
What can you tell us about the other man?
Like I said, I never really saw him. Harold came up, complainin' about the guy - but time I turned, he was gone. FRAN                      MACK
(at Dolly:)               (at Dolly:) Could you de--            Did you get a-- They each stop short, waiting for the other to yield. Fin Mackelway nods, "Go ahead."
Can you describe him, Ma'am?
Sure. He was... Dolly pauses, her face scrunching a bit. Troubled...

That's weird. Guy was in here better part of an hour. We had a real pleasant chat... But I can't remember a thing about him. For the life of me. Couldn't even tell you what color his eyes were. She shrugs apologetically.
Happen to see what he was driving?
That one's easy. It's still in the lot. (they perk up)
The Bonneville out there with the awful paint job. She gestures to the lot, where an old PONTIAC BONNEVILLE its paint stripped down to the primer. Bingo. Fran and Mackelway eye it, then one another.
Fran and Mackelway emerge, heading for the Bonneville.
We ought to work out some kind of protocol.
For what?
Interviews. Witnesses. Looks pretty silly, our talking over one another.

Fine. I'll handle them from now on. He doesn't argue. They come to a stop at that Bonneville, stripped down to its primer. Time to work... Two agents, all instinct. We see them study things, detai their minds always churning... Mackelway pulls out his Mi snaps off a few more shots. Then:

Trunk's ajar. She turns. Sure enough, the Bonneville's trunk is ajar. Mackelway approaches, cautiously. He doesn't have gloves on him, so he uses his jacket pock protect against prints. He opens the trunk. First thing he sees is that SYMBOL again: a circle-with-a slash-through-it... staring right at him.

But this time, it's been carved into somebody's back. Mackelway stares. So does Fran. Before them lies a body, stripped to the waist: a chunky middle-aged MAN. Dead. Mackelway sighs. Things just got tougher...

Harold Speck lies on a table. A BESPECTACLED CORONER exam him. Victim #2, BARNEY FULCHER, lies on another, his ampl frame yet to be examined. The lights are out, but that Coroner wears a FLUORESCENT with a MICROPHONE pinned to his gown. He speaks into it w quiet monotone: anatomical terms, etc. Mackelway and Fran are here... watching. Mackelway is particularly focused on Fulcher's face. His EYELIDS, we n see, have also been torn off. Hmmmm...
Why eyelids?
Huh?
No other signs of torture here. Why take somebody's eyelids off?
So they can't blink. She sighs, aloud: "I know that already, Asshole." Coroner keeps his head down, speaking into that microphone.
It's a metaphor - to make certain the victim sees... or to make certain that we see something. (she's silent)
Or maybe it's just a fuck-you. Coroner continues his monotone narration... then crosses the sink. That puts him out of earshot. So:
(to Fran, quietly)
I'm sorry about Don.
(thrown)
Huh?

You're not wearing your ring anymore. That was an attempt at kindness. She knows that. Still, s eyes her left hand, self-consciously, while Mackelway los himself in those lidless eyes of Fulcher's... Then there's a KNOCK AT THE GLASS WINDOW BEHIND THEM. They turn. Charlton stands on the other side of a GLASS WINDOW, in a VIEWING ROOM adjacent to this Morgue. He pre a piece of paper up against the glass. On it, in typed bold letters at the top, we read: "MATCHE ONE OF ONE." Below that we see that Circle-with-the-slash through-it. This is a FAX, which Charlton's just received. He points further down on the fax at what look like little squiggle first, until we move in to discover it is a hand drawn st map. The ink bleeds a bit due to a poor fax transmission. Thos scrawled lines take us to "The Hope House," in Oklahoma C At the bottom a scribbled name, "David Dyson," and a cont number. Moving closer to the glass, Mackelway nods. He just got a break...

A CHOIR of FIRST AND SECOND GRADERS stands before a schoo assembly. The rest of Boulder Elementary's student body f the seats in here, along with FACULTY MEMBERS. Everybody's weeping. A framed picture of Barney Fulcher s on a stand, with candles around it:
A-may-zing Grace, How sweet the sound--
In the back, some of the TOWNSFOLK have gathered for this assembly, touched. O'Ryan stands among them. No expressio his face at all...

A three-story Victorian residence in decay, next door to CHURCH/SOUP KITCHEN in the middle of Oklahoma City's Skid Rain falls. The street is still. Mackelway approaches this halfway-house. A few lights shi within, and the blue glow of a tv. Upstairs can be heard strident, off-key voice of somebody singing.

The front door is open. Through a SCREEN DOOR, Mackelway see an old-fashioned "foyer." He knocks. Waits. Two sounds dominate: the buzz from that tv, and the strid singing, which we realize is an a capela version of "La V Loca" audible through an open bedroom window. But no one's coming to answer the door, and it's wide ope anyway... So Mackelway enters.
Hello?

TV room is to his left. There, a single 35 year-old DRUNK TRANSIENT (we'll call him "PIPER") sits, watching "Behind Music" on VH1. Tonight's subject? Leif Garret... Piper doesn't look up, or acknowledge Mackelway at all. R he INCREASES THE TV VOLUME to drown out the singing upsta which seems to be intentionally off-key. Torn couches, stained carpet, cracked window. Posters and fliers on the walls. 10 BEDROOMS upstairs.
Agent Mackelway? Mackelway turns. Descending a creaking stairway is DAVID DYSON: 50, lean, with a friendly smile.

We are staring at a BASEMENT WALL that has been covered, to ceiling, with 1,000 identical renderings of that same symbol: the CIRCLE-WITH-A-SLASH-THROUGH-IT. 1,000 of them, in bright red paint, against pitch black enamel. Only a machine could have achieved this kind of repetition. Or a maniac. This basement is leaky, drafty, poorly lit. O'Ryan falls on him, knocking Mackelway hard into the sha CORNER of that furnace, then down to the ground. Mackelwa gun skids across the floor. And his mouth, suddenly, has been covered with gauze.

He wants to fight back... but suddenly he finds that his is swimming. Something's on that gauze. The room is getti fuzzy. We see the belly of a furnace - flames, heat. Then our ow BLOOD... (Mackelway's CHEST was torn open by the corner o that furnace.) Wait. Did we just see the glint of a KNIFE O'Ryan is leaning over us, in utter control. Then O'Ryan's head turns, abruptly - at the sound of FOOTSTEPS. And we hear:
Hey! You! What're you doing down here! We turn, groggily. TWO JANITORS rush toward us, keys jang It's all foggy, wavy, distorted. We see O'Ryan RISE. Then everything goes black...

Mackelway's head is ringing. Feels like he can hear electricity in the walls around him. Slowly, he awakens. him are fluorescent lights. Monitors blink... Fran is here. So's Charlton. Mackelway tries to sit up. T shock of pain from his chest stops him.
How ya doin'? Mackelway half-nods. His chest is bandaged.
We're gonna need everything you can remember about this guy, Tom. Physical description, any kind of distinguishing characteristics. That was terse. Charlton looks pretty pissed-off.
(scratchy)
Where is he?
The suspect fled. Couple janitors walked in on it. (before Mack can ask:)
CHARLTON (CONT'D)
They're fine. But the description they gave of him wasn't worth a damn. Mackelway nods. CHARLTON (CONT'D)
Case you're curious the real Professor Daitz is on sabbatical, out of the country. We can't find him. (Mackelway nods) Whose idea was it to meet there? MACKELWAY
His, Sir. CHARLTON
Uh-huh. Did he ask you to come alone? MACKELWAY
No, Sir. CHARLTON
But you figured you'd get a bigger pat on the head if you wrapped this whole thing up without any help - is that it? The truth? Charlton has him pegged. But: FRAN

Sir, I'm the one who took the call. Agent Mackelway was acting under the assumption that I'd already checked the guy out. We're both to blame. Hold it. That was a major exaggeration, if not an outrigh lie. Mackelway eyes her, thrown. She's poker-faced. Charlton, however, seems unmoved... CHARLTON
Did Agent Mackelway attend the interview unaccompanied? FRAN
(reluctantly) Yes, Sir. CHARLTON
Then whose fuck-up is it? Mackelway eyes her: "Thanks for trying." She nods.
(at Charlton)
It was... poor judgment, Sir.
You wanna work alone, start your own agency. Mackelway can do nothing but nod. Then, bailing him out, another COMPOSITE ARTIST enters, tools in hand. Charlton sighs, frustrated.
(re: Composite Artist)
Let's get you two started. Composite Artist is ready to begin...

A lively Sunday Service. Lots of Baptists, singing a rous spiritual. Music and praise filling the room. We move along the pews, until we came to the very back ro There, one man sits. Alone. Quiet. O'Ryan. Odd expression on his face - it's as if he can't hear thi rousing music, or feel the power of this place. People in next row are stomping their feet. Music soars. But O'Ryan just drops his head, slowly... and begins to W in the middle of this boisterous congregation. Outside, an 18-WHEEL TRUCK can be heard, rumbling by with great force. No one else in here seems to hear it. But O'Ryan shuts his eyes tight, grieving, sobbing...

That TRUCK has just thundered by, leaving a swirl of debr its wake. We TILT UP from it... to find that those STORMC once in the distance are upon us now. And they are pulsing with menace. Rain, wind, lightning, thunder. Like a black wave, about to descend...
One of those five FAX MACHINES begins to ring. Then it be to PRINT.

It's a Sunday. No one's here... but we get a look at what coming in. Same TOP-SHEET again: "Attention Agent Thomas Mackelway" etc. CONTINUE INTERCUT: this incoming fax, set against a few tableaus of Americana. Innocence...

A high school MARCHING BAND is out here, practicing. Cheerleaders work on their routines nearby. Then a LOUD WHISTLE SOUNDS. It's the BAND-LEADER, who is taking note of the weather gathering overhead. The music the band ceases.
Everybody into the gym! The band-members start to move. LIGHTNING erupts overhead
An unnamed MOTHER emerges onto her back-porch, where her YEAR OLD DAUGHTER is having a playdate with a FRIEND. This house borders a wooded area. That wind is starting t make the trees swirl.

Girls, I want you to come in now. Startin' to rain. The girls sigh, disappointed, deciding instead to hide themselves inside the TENT they've erected out here. They giggle. The mother doesn't. CONTINUE INTERCUT:

That fax is now printing page after page. Photos with HAV SEEN ME? across the top and vitals across the bottom. But this time the transmission isn't stopping at five. Th are at least TEN sitting in the tray. Maybe twenty. Faces Eyes. Stats. Locations. Innocence violated...
A SOCCER GAME's been called in the middle of the Second H PARENTS and their uniformed 12 YEAR-OLDS scatter. RAIN is pouring down now, blown sideways by that wind.

That massive, gleaming beast that rumbled past the church rolls right by this park - as all of those kids and their parents scramble for the shelter of their cars. The windshield wipers on this truck push water away, givi a clear look at the wet suburban chaos.
The faithful in here keep singing, their voices full with praise - despite the heavy weather outside. They feel saf here. We move along the PEWS... ...until we find O'Ryan's. He's not here anymore.
O'Ryan leans against the door of the church, pelted by th heavy rain. BAM! Here comes those IMAGES AGAIN:
Tall wheat, whipped by wind and rain. A muzzle-flash. The sound of a body slumping hard to the ground. ...and Mackelway, looking over us. Then:
We're back with O'Ryan. He leans against the door, his torment constant. He walks away from the church, into that heavy rain.
The fax tray has overflown onto the floor - 200 more phot 200 more HAVE YOU SEEN ME's. Forgotten victims. We hear a rumble from that 18-WHEELER. END INTERCUT...
Now there are 800 YELLOW PINS stuck in this map - one for every single FAX or LETTER that's been received in the pa weeks.

800 faces. 800 HAVE YOU SEEN ME's, represented by 800 pin 800 cities. It's like a national plague. Mackelway sits, examining it soberly. His chest-wound is killing him. (We see a thick bandage beneath his shirt.) In his pocket now is a bottle of PRESCRIPTION PILLS. Perc He slugs one down without water, his eyes never straying that map. Beside it is a COMPOSITE DRAWING from O'Ryan, taken from Mackelway's description. It's dead-on...
This is the lone source of light on an otherwise dark str of road. Mackelway's Yukon pulls up.
Hardly a sound in here. Mackelway stands at the register, paying for his TAKE-OUT. Another night with nothing but h thoughts for company. Great. Then:
Agent Mackelway? It's Katie, the receptionist from his office - sitting by herself in a nearby booth. Mackelway smiles.
Hi.

Inexpensive, but furnished with all the touches that Mackelway's apartment lacks: flea-market stuff, lace, ant books, photos from other eras. Character. And candles. Lots of candles. They throw SHADOWS of Macke and Katie all over the walls. An odd MUSIC fills the room, coming from a BOOM-BOX on th floor. It's a rhythmic Navajo CHANT, with Native-American drums providing the pulse. It's eery, tuneless, but awfully authentic... and it fits intensity of the moment: Mackelway and Katie, coupling ma their eyes locked. She's breathless.

First time we've seen him shirtless since his injury in t furnace room. A FAT BANDAGE covers a quarter of his chest Dried blood can be seen beneath it. There's an intensity in his eyes. The chanting, the candl Katie's body, his wound... they've conspired to bring an intensity into his eyes. It's dark, primal. And he's been expressing it for an hour without relent... which is why Katie gasps one last gasp, then rolls to the of the bed, exhausted. She reaches for that boom-box, lowers the volume. The cha dies down into silence. She catches her breath.
(softly)

I can't anymore. Mackelway eyes her, then reaches past her, and turns the VOLUME on that boom-box back UP. The chanting fills the r again. And just like that, he has pulled her back onto him, urge That primal side hasn't been sated yet...

Mackelway stands at the mirror, changing the dressing on wound across his chest. He unwraps the gauze over that fa bandage soaked through with blood. He pulls the bandage off, giving us a better look at the gash. Dried blood, torn skin, bruising. Looks like hell. Mackelway eyes it calmly. He slugs down some beer from a nearby bottle, then cleans wound with some Hydrogen Peroxide... as Katie appears in doorway. She eyes him.
Can't sleep? He shrugs, turns.
What was that music?
It's Navajo. A song for dead warriors. I never played it for anybody before.
(a beat)
Just had a feeling you'd like it.
How?
I dunno. The way you stare when you think nobody's looking. She shrugs. Silence hovers...

4:30 a.m. Rain pounds the window and roof, a real storm o there. The boom box is still. The candles are down to the nubs. Katie continues to sleep. Mackelway too. Then his eyes SNAP OPEN. Something just hit him, something huge. One of those 4:30 the-morning ideas that has to be expressed. Now.
Mackelway stands outside Room 217 at a Mariott. He's just knocked on the door. Fran opens it, in a robe. Very confused. He looks manic.
What're you--
I can't get a read on this guy. Two minutes ago, she was sound asleep.
Huh?

Why is he sending us all this shit? I've got 800 pins in that map, 800 missing people. What's he telling us? She gets it now: he's on a combination of painkillers and of sleep. Or maybe she can sense where he's been...
MACKELWAY (CONT'D)
(rapid-fire) He kills a travelling salesman, then a school-teacher. Then Starkey? It doesn't connect. FRAN
You're a mess... MACKELWAY
I'm fine. I'm clear. I just didn't think this could wait. Fran, this guy is trying to point us at something. Starkey's part of it. But the other two don't connect. FRAN
Did you drive here? MACKELWAY

I'm fine! I just need somebody to think this through with me! He wanted to meet me. It's like he was interviewing me somehow. What is that? Then he kills Starkey. So what was he doing with Speck and Fulcher? FRAN
You wanna come in? MACKELWAY
No. No. You come out. Get dressed. FRAN
Out where? MACKELWAY
I dunno. Somewhere. We're right on the edge of this thing. She studies him. A long beat. FRAN
I'm going back to bed. You're welcome to the couch if you want. I think you could do with some sleep. He sags a bit. She reaches for his hand. FRAN (CONT'D)
(gently) Mack...
Just like that, there is contact. Their hands. It surpris them both. He appreciates it, but now's not the time. So he smiles thinly, turns, and goes. She watches him vanish around a corner.

We've been to this house before. Suburbia. Mackelway sits in his car, at the curb, studying the plac Rain falls in sheets, wind blows. And there he is, all al six in the morning, staring at a house. That idea - the thought that snapped his eyes open - it's still working on him. Beside him is the DRAWING that was in Speck's car: The rendering of a steamer-trunk, lined with plastic, containing body parts in plastic bags... Mackelway seems fixated on it now.
A hand knocks on the front door. Jan Speck opens up.
(hoping for good news:)
Agent Mackelway? Mackelway stands in the doorway, rain falling behind him.
(all business)
Mrs. Speck. Just had a few more questions.
Mackelway sits at the WINDOW, looking over the backyard. Nothing special out here: some trees, a swing, a storm-ce door. But he's staring at it, intently. We're not sure why.
Behind him, Jan re-enters, purse over her shoulder, umbre in hand. She grabs his cup of coffee and saucer from the coffee table. JAN
I'm sorry I don't have more time, Agent Mackelway. It's my PTA Day. MACKELWAY

It's fine. I should've called. She smiles tightly: "I have to go now" and heads for the kitchen. Once she's there, Mackelway turns to the BACK DO and UNLOCKS IT, eyeing that storm-cellar outside... She leaves the cup in the sink. He enters the kitchen. JAN
I hope I was of some help. MACKELWAY
You were. Thanks. JAN
A friend of mine said I'll feel like this one month for every year we were together. Sort of a grieving rule-of- thumb. Have you ever heard that? MACKELWAY
(gently) No. Sorry. She half-smiles. He turns to the door. Turns back. MACKELWAY (CONT'D)
Oh. There was one other thing: Did he keep any kind of chemicals around the house? Acids, that sort of thing? JAN
No. Why? He shrugs, dismissing it: MACKELWAY
It's nothing. Trace elements we found on his trunk. Any interest in chemistry? Maybe as a hobby? Jan pauses for a moment, as if recovering a faint memory. Then she shakes it off. He lets it go.
Anyway, thank you. And thanks for the coffee. Next time I'll call first, I promise.
No trouble at all.

Mackelway sits in his car. Through his windshield we see as she backs out of the driveway. She pulls past us, giving Mackelway as friendly a wave as grieving widow can give. He waves back. Then she's gone, disappearing around a corner. Mackelway pauses a beat, checking his rear-view mirror to sure. Then he gets out of his car...
Mackelway sneaks around the side of the house, pulling on lever to unlatch the side-gate.

He emerges into the tiny backyard, making a bee-line for storm cellar door. He knows he shouldn't be doing this. It's beyond risky. B here he is, without a warrant. There's no lock on the cellar door. He reaches for it. Th stops himself. Just noticed something: A NEIGHBOR-LADY, visible just over Speck's backyard fence looking right at him through her bedroom window. Fuck it. He enters the storm cellar.
Seven steps, leading to a dusty cement floor. Mackelway l around.

Facing him are the things a meticulous man would store in of disaster: Cans of food, sternos, sleeping mats, drums potable water. And long FOOT-LOCKERS. Two of them. That's where Mackelwa eyes go, instantly. He hurries to them. Throws one open. Nothing but sheets and blankets inside. paws through it... finding nothing else. He throws the other trunk open. Inside? Pillows. Fuck. He slams it shut, looks to those cans of food, stacked on shelves. He approaches the shelves, jostling cans from th rows, making more noise than he ought to. But he finds nothing behind them... except more cans. He approaches those two huge drums of water, lugs them aside Behind them is a tall CUPBOARD, locked. He pulls at the cupboard door, hard. It splinters. Inside, a rifle and some boxes of ammo... same as you'd f in every other storm-cellar in Texas. He pauses: Am I crazy...?

He emerges from the storm-cellar, confused. Shuts the sto cellar door. Then he turns. Something else just caught his eye: Above Speck's bedroom window is another window, a tiny on attic... He heads for that UNLOCKED BACK DOOR, and enters...

He hurries toward the stairs, reaches them... then spots something through the Entry Hall window: On the street outside, pulling up to the curb... is a POL CAR. Sirens off. That Neighbor-Lady must've placed the ca And here's Mackelway, without a warrant. Shit. Two ABILENE COPS get out, approaching the house. Mackelwa climbs the stairs.
If he stays quiet, he might just pull this off.

A tiny hallway, with four doors. Up ahead, dangling from ceiling, is a tiny rope which promises a set of hidden fo out stairs... and an attic. Mackelway tugs on the rope. The fold-out stairs drop down of the ceiling. Then he hears:

He's inside! He's inside! Went in through the back! ...which means he has mere seconds before this all blows hell. So he climbs up those fold-out stairs. The two ABILENE COPS now circle the house, entering throu the back-porch door, just as Mackelway did. He pulls up the folding stairs. Maybe the guys'll do a ha assed search and then leave...

Mackelway looks around: lots of dusty junk around here - clothes, mementoes. ...and one more trunk. A steamer-trunk. Huge. And locked. Looks just like the one in that DRAWING rendered by O'Rya Mackelway races for it. Takes out his gun, uses the butt- to bust the lock off. Throws it open. ...as we hear the sound of those fold-out steps, being tu down from the second-floor hallway. And:
Freeze, Asshole! The COP is just ten feet away, most of him still conceale those steps - gun trained right on us. But Mackelway seems utterly untroubled.
(calmly)
It's okay, Fellas. FBI.

I'll bet. Mackelway drops his gun, kicks it toward the cop, who doe quite know what to make of that. Also confusing him is the odd smile playing its way acros Mackelway's face. But we understand it now: The inside of that steamer-trunk is filled with BODY PART bagged, stacked, and sealed in Ziplocs... Powdered LIME is sprinkled on them. Mackelway stares, at once satisfied and sickened. COP #1 be heard, approaching across the attic floor. His gun is drawn... ...until he too sees what's in there.
Oh Jesus Christ...
...a Grammar-School CLASS PICTURE: of Barney Fulcher and 2nd Graders, sitting on a mantle. We are...

That picture sits beside other photos, awards, plaques - celebrating Fulcher's career in Colorado education. We turn away from that mantle, blowing through this modes Living Room, finding an open door - leading down to:

Down the steps we go, until we hear the HUM of an old FRE We turn toward the sound. The freezer is open. A team of FORENSICS GUYS study it. Inside this freezer, frozen into a block of ice... are si female HANDS. No arms, no heads. Just six slender hands, with a wedding band on the ring finger. Mackelway stands in the back of this basement, taking it in. He looks to Charlton, who is expressionless.

102a EXT. FULCHER'S HOUSE - DUSK Close on Mackelway as he returns to his Yukon satisfied. pleased with himself. Out of nowhere, a firm hand grasps right shoulder stopping him. Mackelway turns abruptly, finding himself sandwiched betw his Yukon and Charlton, who is now in his face.
Listen to me Cowboy. You have any idea the kind of favors I had to pull with the Abilene cops to cover your ass?!
Sir...
(not allowing him to talk)
Breaking and ENTERING the Speck house without a shred of evidence and NO
(not going down without a fight)
The sample I took from Speck's bumper... It's crystallized sulfuric acid mixed with oil of Clove, the clove neutralizes the odor of the acid. Charlton shakes his head, he is not getting through.
It was SPECK not his killer who was hiding something.

Ever ask yourself why a big shot agent from Dallas gets sent down to the Wichita Falls Field Office? I'll give you TWO WORDS... Hell I'll even write it down for ya. Charlton leans in to emphasize his point. He pulls out a and pencil from his breast pocket and writes what he says Mackelway's chest as support. It's humiliating.
"EVIDENTIARY PROCEDURE." Don't talk about it. Learn it.
Those words just hang there, haunting Mackelway. Charlton tears off the sheet with those two words and stuffs them Mackelway's hand.

Turns out you were right about this guy. You were right about both of them. But that doesn't change the fact that you went about your business like a rookie. Got it? Charlton turns, the buzz of a street lamp breaks the sile throwing a circle of light around the Yukon. Mackelway wa as Charlton puts on his headlights and drives away. A sudden gust of wind tears that piece of paper out of Mackelway's hand, he stares at it, as it disappears into darkness.

Everything yet known about the murders of Speck, Fulcher, Starkey fills the wall space in here: We see O'Ryan's MAP: All those yellow pins... and the one one, (Greenville, Tx.) Also, that DRAWING: of the ghastly Ziploc bags inside a steamer trunk. Damn thing seems pres now. Agents mill about, awaiting a conference.
(passing by)
Nice job, Mack.
Thanks. A few OTHER AGENTS also pat him on the back. Fran's proud him too - we can see it. In fact everyone in here seems t giving Mackelway his due. It all feels good. Charlton enters.
Seated please. The agents find seats around the table. Charlton takes hi place at the head of it.
(to the assembled:)
Okay. We've got a serial killer of serial killers. Fran scribbles something on a piece of paper: "What a gen Slides it over. Mackelway conceals the note, as:
(still grand-standing)

He's a transient with a history of mental illness. He also happens to think he's a former agent of this Bureau. And he is pursuing something that he calls "Suspect Zero." Anybody got anything intelligent to say? Nobody's volunteering.   There's just silence.
(familiar refrain)
That's what I thought...
Mackelway exits the office, heading for his Yukon. Then he stops... because Katie is waiting out here, leani against her Toyota Camry.
(fondly)
Hey.
Somethin', huh? Guy with a wife and kids keepin' bodies in his attic? He nods... but what is she doing out here?
Yeah. (a beat)
You okay?
Yeah. Just... Wondered if you could do me a favor.

Mackelway waits... as Katie hands over a manila envelope. Mackelway opens it. Inside, a photo of a heartbreakingly-sweet 22 year-old gi named KAREN SUMPTER, with an attached sheet listing her vitals: height, weight, age, etc. Another face. Another disappearance...
Her name's Karen Sumpter. We were friends. (almost reluctantly)
She disappeared last year. Nobody knows where. She was a little wild, but not like that. Her sadness is obvious. Mackelway nods.
Anyway, I know you're gonna be in on the autopsies - of the girls they found over at Speck's. Figured you might see if one of 'em was... Her voice trails off. This is hard.
If it is, I'd like to be the one to notify her folks. Out families've been friends for years.
(gently)
Sure. Of course.
Thanks... 'Night. Mackelway puts the envelope under his arm. She starts up Camry. The sky rumbles. He eyes her. For some reason, she hasn't pulled away yet...
Candles. Shadows on the wall...and Mackelway and Katie, a again, with the sounds of that eery Navajo CHANTING comin from the boom-box.

Mackelway is studying her, staring into her eyes, her breathing. She's beginning to climax now... and those eye wider. We MOVE INTO THEM, and: We are abruptly SLAMMED, again, INTO ANOTHER SET OF THOSE DISJOINTED IMAGES from that unidentified place:
Wet wind in a blur of gray. The sound of our own heavy breathing. A voice rising above the wind, pleading:
Please...

She is utterly lost now. And that CHANTING seems to have gotten louder somehow. IMAGES FLICK at us now: culled from that BOOK on TRIBAL R AND TRANCE, found at the halfway house: a TRIBESMAN with rolling back in his head, foaming at the mouth. Mackelway tries to shake it off, tries to keep his focus Katie. He buries his head into her neck, as:
Tall wheat, wet wind. Then a MUZZLE FLASH, and a body slu to the ground. And suddenly we are in:
O'Ryan, at a desk. He has just "remote viewed" these imag somehow. And they've left him rattled. It's time to get out of this room. Quickly.
A stolen, non-descript CHEVY pulls out of a motel room pa lot, on to the street.
O'Ryan is behind the wheel, driving.

The radio is BLASTING - anything to shake those images ou his head. Driving, unsettled... which may be why he doesn notice that there's a SIREN wailing behind him. He looks in the rear-view. A TEXAS STATE TROOPER is on hi tail. Shit. O'Ryan tightens, pulling over...
The TROOPER approaches, noting the condition of the vehic He stands before O'Ryan's window. O'Ryan's face reveals n evidence at all of anxiety.
Evening.
Evening, Officer.
See your license, Sir?

'Course. Is there a problem? O'Ryan reaches into his back pocket, produces an I.D. Han over. Trooper eyes it. According to this i.d., we are now stari "James Garvey" from Littleton, Colorado. But the Trooper doesn't seem too convinced.
See your registration, please?
Sure. O'Ryan opens up the glove compartment, starts searching through it. But it's a stall, that's obvious.
Mind stepping out of the car, please? O'Ryan pauses. There is no way in hell he's going to let himself get deterred by a State Trooper. But he gets out.
Trooper eyes him with caution. O'Ryan holds his hands in of his chest, keeping them visible to the guy.
O'RYAN
Officer, I am carrying something that could be construed as a weapon. I'd like to hand it over, voluntarily, so you won't think I'm trying to conceal anything. Would that be all right? TROOPER
What kind of weapon, Sir? O'RYAN
It's a hunting knife, right here on my hip. Trooper notes the shape of that large, sheathed KNIFE - t one O'Ryan butchered Starkey with - visible beneath O'Rya shirt. O'RYAN (CONT'D)
I was on my way to the woods. My gear's in the trunk. (Trooper doubts it) Would you like me to hand it to you? I don't know what the procedure is for something like this. TROOPER
Take the weapon off your hip, place it on the ground, and kick it toward me. O'RYAN
Happy to. O'Ryan takes the knife off his hip. The size of it gets s attention from the Trooper. TROOPER
What exactly were you planning on hunting, Sir? O'RYAN
A fifty-foot shark. No reply. O'Ryan drops the menacing knife to the ground a kicks it toward the Trooper. Trooper, slowly, kneels down to get it - never taking his off O'Ryan. O'RYAN (CONT'D)
Ya know, I used to be in law enforcement too.
(kneeling)
That right?
Mmm-hmmm. FBI. 'Course this was some years ago. Trooper grabs the knife, straightens. Examines it.
Psy Ops. Classified.
Had anything to drink tonight, Sir? Under medication of any kind? An 18-WHEEL TRUCK rumbles by, distracting O'Ryan... rende him immobile for a moment.
Sir?
Oh. Sorry. Just found myself wondering what was inside that truck.
Sir, I'm going to ask you to hand me the keys to your vehicle, please.

Of course. O'Ryan opens the car door. We steal a look INSIDE. ...he's got a GUN under the front seat. In a flash, that gun is in his hands and pointing right a forehead of that Trooper. Trooper knows he's been had. And he knows that he's about die...
Mackelway approaches, carrying a greasy bag: another Frit and a soda. Fumbles with his keys... Then he notices something, waiting on his doorstep.

It's a thick FILE, roughly 150 pages, in a FOLDER. The wo "MACKELWAY" is written across the front. He leans down, opens the folder. The light is spotty out here... but it's just strong enough to show us the expres on his face: a look of pure awe.
The door bursts open. The greasy bag and the soda fall to floor. Mackelway hurries to a phone, clutching that file. dials hurriedly.
We're in a PARKING LOT outside a WAL-MART. Fran's just th a bag into her Ford Taurus. Her CEL-PHONE RINGS. She grab
Kulok.
He really was FBI.
Huh?

O'Ryan. He left his file on my doorstep. Fran, he was FBI. He can barely believe it himself, but we get a look at wh was in that file now; PAGES are splayed across Mackelway' coffee table: A copy of an FBI I.D. BADGE, xeroxed memoes, test scores, citations, evaluations, reports. The entire career of Spe Agent Benjamin O'Ryan... in black and white.
That's impossible.
I'm look at his whole history! Citations, letters of commendation, even his fucking test scores from Quantico. The guy was an agent.
I don't believe it.
Listen to me--
Then we hear a BEEP. Call-Waiting. Great. MACKELWAY (CONT'D)
Shit! Hold on. That irritated her. Mackelway clicks over. MACKELWAY (CONT'D)
Yes? O'RYAN (THRU PHONE)
Read anything interesting lately? Mackelway's eyes go wide. MACKELWAY
Where are you? CLICK. O'Ryan's just hung up. MACKELWAY (CONT'D)
Shit! He stares at the phone, then clicks over again, re-connec to Fran. MACKELWAY (CONT'D)
That was him. FRAN
He called you at home? MACKELWAY
Yes. BEEP. Call-Waiting again. FRAN
Jesus. Call me back. Mackelway clicks over again without saying goodbye. MACKELWAY (INTO PHONE)
O'Ryan? O'RYAN (THRU PHONE)
I've found him, you know. MACKELWAY
Who? O'RYAN
Zero.
MACKELWAY
Zero's a myth. You made him up. O'RYAN
Myths don't kidnap little boys. Do they? MACKELWAY
Do you? Sounds like O'Ryan just laughed... Then, another curve: O'RYAN
Was she pretty? MACKELWAY
Huh? O'RYAN

I could hear her moaning, right under the Navajo chanting. Whole thing was downright tribal. What's she look like? That was unsettling. Very. Mackelway looks around feeling violated, feeling "watched." He draws the blinds. Double the front door. Runs his hand under the window frame for kind of wire tapping. But Mackelway won't allow himself to over-react. Not now, O'Ryan on the phone. MACKELWAY
(calmly) You tell me. O'Ryan laughs. He liked that. O'RYAN
Fair enough. We'll stick to business: How'd ya like my old room? MACKELWAY
Huh? O'RYAN
"Hope House." You were there. How the hell did he know that? It's unsettling. O'RYAN (CONT'D)
Dyson re-paint it? (no reply) My room. Did he re-paint it?
Yeah. White.
